name: 1 TERRY apple label writing card
description:
One 15cm x 10.5cm   M. B. Terry & Son folded card with quality envelope in a cellophane bag

Blank inside with label history information on the back

My latest printing is on 70% recycled card with modified script on the back mentioning the Apple Pip, my parents roadside stall at Hayes.  In the 1970s & 1980s it was a favourite stop for those returning to the west coast and for Sunday drivers.  Sundays were very busy.   My mother, Margie baked thousands of apple cakes which were often served with whipped cream and a spoon.  Her cream filled sponge cakes were very popular too.  After church on Sundays, Mum would take delivery of a bootload of immaculate biscuits, cakes & slices made by Dad's cousin, Lynette James.  

Over the years Dad grew earlier varieties and later ones to lengthen the season of fruit available at the Apple Pip. It was a very busy productive time. Many will remember his fibreglass apple on top of the shop which is still there.

name: 1 PEACOCK apple label writing card - yellow surround
description:
One 15cm x 10.5cm 'W.D. Peacock' folded writing card with a quality envelope in a cellophane bag.   
Blank inside with information about the apple labels on the back.

William Davidson Peacock (1847-1921) was born in Gloucestershire and emigrated to Melbourne at the age of 14 to work in his Uncle George's jam factory. In 1885 he was dismissed after refusing to manage a jam factory attached to a distillery, which offended his strong temperance principles. In 1889, aged 42, he established his own jam factory at Salamanca, and in 1895 entered the European fruit export trade. Peacock was a pioneer in guaranteeing full cargo space to induce European ships to take on fruit in Tasmanian ports. Previously, exporters had to ship export fruit to the mainland. 
By 1898, Peacock and Henry Jones were sharing this high-risk strategy. Their companies dominated the Tasmanian fruit export industry. In 1910, Henry Jones IXL secretly purchased Peacock's company, retaining Peacock as manager till his retirement in 1918. 

By then Peacock's factories had expanded into 5 Salamanca warehouses between Kelly Street and Wooby's Lane. The Peacock Theatre, in this location, was named after him. 
The W.D. Peacock & Co label was used from 1927 when Salamanca was the centre for apple & pear exporting.

name: One W.D. Peacock folding card with red surround
description:
blank inside - includes a quality envelope 

William Davidson Peacock (1847-1921) was born in Gloucestershire and emigrated to Melbourne at the age of 14 to work in his Uncle George's jam factory. In 1885 he was dismissed after refusing to manage a jam factory attached to a distillery, which offended his strong temperance principles. In 1889, aged 42, he established his own jam factory at Salamanca, and in 1895 entered the European fruit export trade. Peacock was a pioneer in guaranteeing full cargo space to induce European ships to take on fruit in Tasmanian ports. Previously, exporters had to ship export fruit to the mainland. 
By 1898, Peacock and Henry Jones were sharing this high-risk strategy. Their companies dominated the Tasmanian fruit export industry. In 1910, Henry Jones IXL secretly purchased Peacock's company, retaining Peacock as manager till his retirement in 1918. By then Peacock's factories had expanded into 5 Salamanca warehouses between Kelly Street and Wooby's Lane. The Peacock Theatre, in this location, was named after him. 
The W.D. Peacock & Co label was used from 1927 when Salamanca was the centre for apple & pear exporting.

name: 1 BEAUTIFUL ISLE apple label card
description:
One 15cm x 10.5cm   Tasmanian 'Beautiful Isle' folded writing card with a quality envelope in a cellophane bag.

Blank inside with information about the apple labels on the back.

Henry Jones began working at George Peacock's Melbourne Jam Factory  in 1874.  In 1891 he established his H. Jones & Co company, and subsequently bought George's Jam Factory, moving it to the Jam Factory site in Chapel St, Melbourne. He then set up his IXL Jam Factory in Hunter St, Hobart, so named because his personal motto was 'I excel in everything I do'. There is still much evidence of  the IXL Jam Factory around the Henry Jones Art Hotel and atrium in Hunter St. The Beautiful Isle brand dates from 1936.
